data.title: Wrong parameter used in BeginShowMessageBox
ContentManager.RemoveContentManager called in a wrong place.
data.body:
Version: 2.5.1 release
File: MonoGame.Framework\Content\ContentManager.cs
Method: Unload
Line: 527

I noticed that MonoGame uses a static field ContentManager.ContentManagers to track all the created content manager, but RemoveContentManager was called in ContentManager.Unload. According to XNA's document, this method only unloads all assets that was loaded, and the user are free to call Load<T> afterwards. In MonoGame, this approach will cause the ContentManager to be lost tracked, thus ContentManager.ReloadAllContent will not have effect on that one (although I didn't found where this method was called ^_^)

Suggestion fix: move the "RemoveContentManager(this);" to "protected virtual void Dispose(bool disposing)", right after "Unload();"

data.title: WinRT Backbuffer Auto-Sizing
data.body:
This is based on discussions from these threads...

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/720
http://monogame.codeplex.com/discussions/382915

The issue is that people want the Game/GameWindow to automatically set the backbuffer size to the client size, but also if they set a different backbuffer size then they want to maintain that ratio when the window goes into the snapped or filled states.

So with this pull we now...
- We store a scale between the client size and the preferred backbuffer size the user set in the Game constructor if any.
- When the client resizes we calculate the new preferred backbuffer size using that scale.
- We then fire off the application view state event and the client size changed events... this is the users chance to override our settings if they want to.

It would be great if a few people could test this branch with their own projects before we decide to merge it.

data.title: Don't assume ushort indices, uint are also supported for index buffers
data.body:
DrawIndexedPrimitives assumed that the index buffer used unsigned shorts. This fix makes it possible to use unsigned integers as well, as the rest of the system supports it.
This resolved a geometry corruption issue in my project.

data.title: WriteableBitmap - WinRT
data.body:
I have noticed that the use of WriteableBitmap throws cross-thread error when used inside the game loop on Windows 8.

See my SO post here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12182082/monogame-windows-8-bitmapfactory

It is strange, because I feel the game loop should already be on the main UI thread.

data.title: ContentTypeReaderManager - ability to create readers explicitly from type strings for iOS
data.body:
Since MonoTouch can not JIT certain types (generics of value types seem to be the main offenders), this change allows us to intercept the type creation and provide a creator function for any type string. 

Some notes:
- Since reader types are often based off generic readers, I had to make these generic readers public. 
- Where the type is completely built in, I've added it to the existing block of placeholder-types. 
- I've caught the exception when type creation fails and thrown a new one with a tailor made MonoGame related message.

data.title: Develop3d - Fix Android touch disabled when SupportedOrientations changed after game started
data.body:
Main issue being fixed: https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/685
Also some discussion was had about the issue in this related thread: http://monogame.codeplex.com/discussions/390731

As a side effect of this change, MonoGame is only internally calling ApplyChanges() once at startup (unless orientation is changed).

Note that there are still some screen scaling issues, particularly when not in fullscreen mode. Fixing this is much more involved so should be left as a different task.

data.title: SpriteBatch-based 3D Billboards not drawing
data.body:
Shawn Hargreaves documented a method of drawing 3D billboards with SpriteBatch http://blogs.msdn.com/b/shawnhar/archive/2011/01/12/spritebatch-billboards-in-a-3d-world.aspx.

The Tranquillity particle system (http://tranquillity.codeplex.com/) is based on this method. It works on the phone and in Windows with XNA. The particles do not, however, show up with MonoGame's SpriteBatch when tested with Windows 8 as a modern app.

The steps to reproduce the code are in Shawn Hargreaves' article. The easier way is to simply grab Tranquillity's code (builds and runs in MonoGame without a hiccup).

data.title: iOS - RenderTarget cropped
data.body:
I noticed that when you create a rendertarget that does not match the size of the screen perfectly, it will not work properly in most cases. For example if you swap the width and height parameters in the RenderTarget2D sample, you get the following image (the red rectangle is what it's real size should be):

![Simulator](http://kepfeltoltes.hu/120825/rendertarget_www.kepfeltoltes.hu_.png)

GraphicsDevice.Clear() works properly, but something is not right with drawing. Chaning the viewport used in the rendertarget can make the game draw correctly. For example, when using a 320x320 rendertarget, a viewport of (0, 160, 320, 320) seems to work. For a 320x240 renderarget, a viewport of (0, 240, 320, 320) is required, so the top left position is not set correctly when drawing.

data.title: SpriteBatch.Draw called, but SpriteBatch.Begin was not called
data.body:
Hi all,

I've started an application yesterday and i did a little mistake, I forgot to call the SpriteBatch.Begin() method. 

So, when i called the SpriteBatch.Draw() method, an excpetion (NullReferenceExcpetion) happened in GraphicsDevice.GetInputLayout(DXShared, VertexDeclaration) method.

It's happening because the _vertexShader is null until i call SpriteBatch.Begin(). However, according to the XNA api, an InvalidOperationException exception should be thrown (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff433986.aspx).

data.title: iOS - TouchPanel reporting Pressed and Moved multiple times
data.body:
We use our own manager to handle touches, based on the pressed-moved-released events. We noticed that with monogame, the touch panel's touches remain in pressed state for multiple frames (happens with 60FPS and 30FPS too, so this is not related to the framerate). Here is what it looks like when I quickly tap the screen 5 times with 30 FPS (P is Pressed, R is Released event):
PPR PPR PPPR PR PR
With 60FPS I get Pressed 4 to 6 times.
The same happens with the moved event.
The "state isn't dirty, should not be updated" thing never happens in the TouchPanel's GetState() function. Yet the TouchPanel is not properly updated.

A picture of the issue:
![MonoDevelop](http://kepfeltoltes.hu/120825/touchpanel_www.kepfeltoltes.hu_.png)

This seems to happen because the pressed event is sent again and again until there is a moved event. The moved events are being sent again until there is a new moved event. This should normally not happen. Reporting the same moved event multiple times leads to huge issues (using the delta will be impossible). What's with the device's touchscreen polling rate?
